title: Question 22

children: A 28-year-old woman is evaluated for sleepiness and difficulty staying awake over the past 6 months. She works as a hospital respiratory therapist. Half of her shifts are from 7:00
PM
AM

. The sleepiness subsides by the time she drives home, and she then has difficulty falling asleep during the day. Her sleepiness has slowed her cognitive processing during working hours and has resulted in depressed mood.
On physical examination, blood pressure is 118/68 mm Hg and pulse rate is 76/min. BMI is 24.
Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
Conservative strategies for shift work sleep disorder to promote wakefulness include caffeinated beverages, bright-light exposure during the work shift, and short naps during breaks.

Conservative strategies for shift work sleep disorder to promote sleep include avoidance of direct sunlight in the early morning and avoidance of exertion, eating, and alcohol consumption before the morning sleep period.
The most appropriate management is education and counseling (
Option A

). As much as one fifth of the American work force maintains a job schedule outside of usual day shift hours. Although some people acclimate well to this schedule, many experience excessive sleepiness, mood perturbations, and neurocognitive dysfunction. Symptoms persisting at least 3 months meet the criteria for shift work sleep disorder. Management should first include counseling that takes into consideration eliminating shift work. If this is not feasible, then education about symptom management should be pursued. This patient has difficulty falling asleep after her nighttime shift. Education on avoidance of direct sunlight in the early morning (using sunglasses or a dark bedroom) and avoidance of exertion, eating, and alcohol consumption before the morning sleep period should be provided. Daytime sleepiness may respond to use of caffeinated beverages, bright-light exposure during the work shift, and if feasible, a short (30-minute) nap, perhaps during a meal break.
Home sleep apnea testing (
Option B

), which uses respiratory tools and/or noninvasive measurements of vascular tone, pulse oximetry, and an accelerometer to detect posture, is indicated when there is strong pretest evidence of obstructive sleep apnea. The suspicion of obstructive sleep apnea in a young woman of normal weight is low; in addition, her main symptoms are difficulty falling asleep and associated daytime sleepiness. If the patient's symptoms persist after conservative therapy, in-laboratory polysomnography could be considered for a more comprehensive evaluation.
Modafinil (
Option C

), a novel stimulant, is approved to treat shift work sleep disorder. It should be considered only after conservative measures have failed. Modafinil is limited by cost and adverse effects, including headache, anxiety, and (rarely) serious skin reactions.
Hypnotic medications such as zolpidem (
Option D

) have been used to promote daytime sleep but are of varying effectiveness and pose a risk of carryover effects into the work period. Pharmacologic agents are considered second-line treatments to counseling, education, and other nonpharmacologic interventions.

references: Reis C, Staats R, Pellegrino P, et al. The prevalence of excessive sleepiness is higher in shift workers than in patients with obstructive sleep apnea. J Sleep Res. 2020;29:e13073.
